Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computation of instantons in complex nonlinear systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
A wide variety of systems exhibit rare events -- events far from the average system behavior with low probability of occurring. Rare events can have significant consequences, and improved understanding of their occurrence can aid in the design or management of such systems. The characterization of the likelihood of rare events is essential in all systems in which stochasticity plays an important role, as it allows us to take advantage of such events if they are desirable and to avoid them if they present a threat. The outcomes of this project will contribute to the understanding of rare events in complex systems, in particular, fluid dynamics and related geophysical systems. Further applications include the characterization of extreme events in the context of epidemics, population dynamics, and molecular biology.

The goal of this project is to develop efficient computational methods to characterize the most likely way rare events occur in complex stochastic systems and to estimate the tails of their probability distributions. For this purpose, the investigators will develop efficient algorithms to compute the so-called "instantons" that are minimizers of the action functional that large deviation theory associates with the stochastic differential equation describing the system's evolution. Numerical methods to calculate instantons will first be developed in the context of turbulence (in particular Burgers equation, magneto-hydrodynamics (MHD), Navier-Stokes equations, and the surface-quasi-geostrophic (SQG) equation) driven by diffusive processes. Then the investigators will extend the methods to stochastic equations that are driven by non-Markovian noise (fractional Brownian motion) or jump-processes, which play an important role in physics, biology, and chemistry. Finally, the investigators will calculate fluctuations around the instantons to get finer estimates of their probability of occurrence via prefactor calculations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was the development of mathematical and computational tools to determine the probability of extreme events in complex stochastic systems. Extreme events are events that occur rarely, but have large impact when they happen. In earth sciences, for example, such events are hurricanes, floods, or earthquakes. Extreme events also play a crucial role in other fields like biology, epidemics, physics, or chemistry. Having efficient computational tools at hand to determine the likelihood of such events can help to increase preparedness, perform a better scenario analysis, or improve disaster management.

The starting point of the work was the computation of so-called instantons which in many cases can be thought of as the likeliest path of a stochastic system leading from a stable configuration to an extreme event. Determining instantons is computationally challenging, and, within the work for this project, efficient algorithms were developed to accelerate their computation. Among many applications, a particular example to demonstrate the computational efficiency of these methods was the computation of instantons for the cubic nonlinear Schroedinger equation (NLSE), a basic equation in nonlinear optics which has applications in the context of fiber optics and laser physics.
A second set of results of the work performed within this project concerns the incorporation of fluctuations around the instanton. This is of crucial importance for the computation of probabilities of extreme events as, in many cases, an approximation of this probability is determined by two contributions: One coming from the action of the instanton and a second part, the so-called prefactor, stemming from the fluctuations around the instanton. While previous approaches allowed to make statements about the scaling properties of probabilities, these new algorithms allow for an efficient approximate computation of the probability itself which makes the results more useful in practice.
